Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Grant: Improving Learning in Engineering by Introducing a Writing-to-Learn Component to Quantitative Problem-Solving Tasks

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research initiation grant will investigate how to implement writing techniques that enable engineering students to develop broad technical problem-solving skills. Such problem solving is a key outcome of engineering degree programs. The techniques developed are expected to be easily incorporated into existing engineering degree programs.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be in the area of student development, and creation of the engineering workforce. Student participants are expected to develop both as engineers and future researchers. This project overlaps with NSF's strategic goals of transforming the frontiers through preparation of an engineering workforce with new capabilities and expertise. Additionally NSF's goal of innovating for society is enabled by supporting the development of innovative learning systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary goal of this project was to develop a practical writing-to-learn exercise that encourages students to think about, articulate and reflect upon their confusion about concepts taught in an engineering statics class. We anticipated that this metacognitive (self-reflective) activity would result in students having an improved understanding of course material, as manifested by improved course performance. Secondarily, it is was our goal that students perceive the writing-to-learn exercise to be useful, and that it has the potential to affect their approach to problem-solving beyond the semester that the writing intervention is implemented.

Over the duration of the project the writing exercise evolved in response to student and faculty feedback on the utility and practicality of the exercise. The final iteration included both self-questioning and revision components. After students solved selected engineering problems at home, they were asked in class to write about any confusion they had about the concepts or computations required to solve the problems. They were also asked to write a question to help clarify their confusion. The professor then demonstrated the solution as students corrected their own work; the professor also encouraged students to share any of their written questions with the class. Finally, students revisited their initial response and wrote out their revised understanding of the problem.

We implemented this form of the writing exercise in three sections of an introductory statics course; one section was taught in the spring and two were taught the following fall, all by the same instructor. The three sections included a total of 69 students.  The efficacy of the writing intervention was assessed via student performance in the course compared to control semesters that did not include the intervention, as well as through written survey and interviews of students’ experiences with the intervention. For all intervention and control semesters, anonymous pre-requisite course grades (in math and physics) and high school GPA data were compiled to compare student preparedness across semesters.

The results show that course grades were higher for students who participated in the intervention than for those who were in the control semesters. However, we also found that prerequisite grades were also higher for the students in the intervention group. This cohort effect make it difficult to directly observe the potential quantitative impact of the intervention.

Survey and interview responses suggest that students found aspects of the questionnaire interventions useful. There were largely positive ratings on the utility of questionnaire, and some students noted in their open-ended responses that they felt as though it added to their ability to think about what they understood about the concepts covered in class. One very enthusiastic student even said the intervention inspired her to use this evaluation technique in her other courses. 

These positive student comments indicate that students seem receptive to this kind of pedagogical approach. We specifically designed this intervention such that student efforts were directed towards an activity that is a natural part of the problem-solving process (identifying areas of confusion) and would hopefully be perceived to be of benefit to them. Student perception of the task’s efficacy is an important factor in its ability to be implemented successfully, since whether students appreciate the utility of an exercise is a large factor in determining whether they will put effort into it.

In summary, while cohort effects obscured our ability to quantify the influence of our intervention on student performance, many students found the writing exercise to be of value in helping them to better understand and resolve their confusion about Statics concept...
